discussion.content: he dd command can be used to create a USB storage media from a disk image. The dd command stands for "data duplicator" and is used to copy data from one source to another. In this case, you would use the dd command to copy the contents of a disk image to a USB drive, creating a bootable USB storage media.

questions.question_text: Which of the following commands can be used to create a USB storage media from a disk image?
A user accidentally created the subdirectory \dir in his home directory. Which of the following commands will remove that directory?
Which of the following commands will send output from the program myapp to both standard output (stdout) and the file file1.log?

What is the output of the following command?
echo "Hello World" | tr -d aieou

discussion.content:
C.Hll Wrid

The "echo" command outputs the string "Hello World". The pipe symbol "|" sends the output from the echo command as input to the next command, "tr".

The "tr" command is used to translate or delete characters from the input. In this case, the option "-d" is used to delete characters and the argument "aieou" specifies the characters to be deleted.

So, the output of the command "echo "Hello World" | tr -d aieou" will be "Hll Wrld", as all the vowels 'a', 'i', 'e', 'o', 'u' have been deleted.

questions.question_text: Which of the following characters can be combined with a separator string in order to read from the current input source until the separator string, which is on a separate line and without any trailing spaces, is reached?

discussion.content:
<<" is a shell operator used in shell scripts to specify the "here document" redirection. It is used to read from the current input source until a specified delimiter string is reached. The format for the here document is as follows:

command << delimiter
input data
delimiter

The input data between the delimiter and the second appearance of the delimiter is passed as standard input to the command. The delimiter string must appear on a line by itself, with no trailing spaces.
